video.title: Yakuza 6: The Song of Life (Zero Punctuation)

captions.text:
So after God of War was about Kratos taking
his pet semen sample for a walk, it&#39;s no secret

that I think that narrative triple-A games
have a preponderance of serious hairy dad
games right now.

Almost certainly because game developers and
veteran players are now old enough to be dads

themselves and want to envision a world in
which their families actually respect them.

All I&#39;m saying is, surely there are other
kinds of people with stories worth telling
besides serious hairy dads.

Why don&#39;t we ever hear about serious hairy
mums?

You know, games in which jaded and battle-weary
mums escort their helpless child as they kick

down the door of a Jamba Juice and demand
to speak to the manager.
Oh wait a second, does Bayonetta 1 count?

Well anyway, let&#39;s play Yakuza 6, hopefully
there won&#39;t be so many poignant lessons about

fatherhood in a game centred around stoving
faces in with other people&#39;s bicycles - oh
for fucks sake there&#39;s a baby.

A baby that the hardened, permanently scowling
Dragon of Dojima Kazuma Kiryu has to amuse

in a baby amusing minigame where we swing
him about like a sack of spuds to fill the
baby amusement meter.

Well, are you still surprised by the range
of weird side activities in Yakuza games,
Yahtz?

But this isn&#39;t side activity, this is critical
path!

And worth mentioning because virtually everything
else on the critical path is the same shit

one should always expect from Yakuza - there&#39;s
a massively convoluted plot to take over Japan

that Kazuma Kiryu discovers and foils basically
by accident during a personal investigation

he started pursuing after he got really cross
about a beautiful innocent lady being dishonored.

And the story is told through a series of
prolonged scenes of very serious-faced men

staring at each other saying ominous things
until they get bored and start hitting each
other with bikes.

There&#39;s one particularly hilarious scene where
one dude starts splashing gasoline around

and the other dude just continues to sit angrily
staring at him because it&#39;s literally the

only way anyone in these games knows how to
deal with situations.

&quot;Maybe the match will go out if I scowl slightly
harder at it.&quot;

This time, as well as the usual dicking about
in Kamurocho we get to spend time in Hiroshima,

where the plot eventually centres around a
mysterious secret that the town&#39;s leaders
will stop at nothing to keep covered up.

Which I don&#39;t want to spoil, so let&#39;s just
say it&#39;s a giant robot brontosaurus.
Frankly it might as well have been that.

It&#39;s about as absurd, and in the end what
it actually is doesn&#39;t seem to matter a tinker&#39;s
fanny flap &#39;cos it never DOES anything.

Kazuma Kiryu never gets to ride on top of
the giant robot brontosaurus or slide gaily

down its tail like on the Flintstones, it
just shows up looming over the houses and

all the characters look at each other and
go &quot;Welp, secrets out, time to take our shirts
off and start decking each other.&quot;

This is all part of why I love Yakuza games
- they&#39;re hilariously fucking dumb and yet
so earnest you can&#39;t help getting invested.

Having said that, Yakuza 6 definitely feels
lacking compared to its predecessors - Kiryu

is the only player character, the new Hiroshima
sandbox is kinda low on content and even Kamurocho

feels a bit deader than usual, it wouldn&#39;t
even let me play on the skill testers at the

batting cages, and they haven&#39;t even tried
to mix up the standard combat like Yakuza

0 did with switching around the main character&#39;s
favourite part of Neapolitan ice cream, it&#39;s

just the usual punch, kick, stomp, bike to
the face combat.

Incredibly unbalanced combat, as well, nothing
seems to be nearly as effective as picking

up a bench and flailing it around, that just
wrecks shit like a high fibre diet.

And when there are no benches, I eventually
discovered that even the final boss is made

your cringing shirtless bitch if you just
keep knocking them down with flying dropkicks.
Don&#39;t you see, Kazuma Kiryu?
The bench was in you all along!

The only major shakeup to the core gameplay
is a levelling system where the XP is split

between five stats, strength, defense, sage,
rosemary and umami.

And this doesn&#39;t really add much except a
delightful rainbow colour scheme to enjoy

as I go down my stat screen half-heartedly
mashing the A button to make them go up.

If the intention was to try to encourage specialisation
then it was a misguided one because Kiryu

is only ever called upon to deck people and
none of the stats do much to change the effect

of picking up a bench and going on a mandible
safari.

But I think it&#39;s finally clear to me that
the draw of Yakuza games absolutely isn&#39;t
the main plot or the critical path.

Look, I&#39;m gonna spoil every fucking Yakuza
game&#39;s main plot now: early in the game there&#39;ll

be a scene where you have a growly voice angry
stare sit down meeting with someone important

that doesn&#39;t end in a fist fight, someone
in that meeting is the main villain.

Probably someone shifty-looking off to the
side.

At the end of the game, after the bit where
everyone puts on dark suits and walks slowly

down the street as the we&#39;re-done-fucking-around
music plays like we&#39;re going to a West Side

Story-themed funeral, they&#39;ll be the one who
pulls their breakaway suit jacket off to reveal

their torso&#39;s built like a fucking double
decker bus with a Chronicles of Narnia poster
on the back.

So forget all that, it is the side stuff that
makes Yakuza games, that are usually the thing

to make me start laughing until my buttocks
fly off into a sandwich.

One highlight for me this time around was
the sexy internet chatroom minigame.

Where a live action video of a sexy lady plays
as we have to complete a series of button

prompts to type phrases like &quot;YOU ARE SEXY
LADY&quot; and &quot;MMMM LOVELY BOOBS&quot; in all caps,

and I think what really made this for me was
the image of Kazuma Kiryu typing in the bottom

left still wearing the furious scowl he uses
to confront dastardly villains.

And then of course there are the numerous
side stories wherein Kiryu demonstrates his

unending willingness to humiliate himself
at the request of random strangers.

And none of this would be as funny as it is
without the very serious main plot, which

is as good a justification for its existence
as any.

When we agree to put on a mascot costume to
amuse the kiddies it&#39;s funnier because it&#39;s

the Dragon of Dojima in there making a happy
mascot pose, who half an hour ago made a roomful

of Yakuza captains piss themselves because
his left eyebrow slightly twitched.

Oh yes, and in keeping with every Yakuza game
having a &#39;main&#39; side activity - like the real

estate stuff in Zero or Akiyama&#39;s hostess
club stroke blue ball factory in Yakuza 4
- this time around we have a street gang simulator.

Yeah, I can tell you&#39;re serious about leaving
the Yakuza life behind, Kiryu, that must be

why you exclusively hang out with Yakuza and
casually started a fucking street gang.

We develop a fraternity of disillusioned young
people and fling them Pokemon-style at enemy

gangs in a series of contained real time strategy
battles.

Or rather, real time &quot;press the button to
spawn dudes&quot; battles for there isn&#39;t much
strategy involved.

I only played four or five of them but they
all took place on perfectly straight roads

with nary a chance for even the simplest pincer
movement.

About the only strategy I figured out was
to only spawn the big tank top dudes at the

start of the battle &#39;cos otherwise it takes
so long for them to saunter leisurely into

action that by the time they get there it&#39;ll
all be over and everyone will have pissed
off to the ice cream social.

In case it wasn&#39;t clear I&#39;m not impressed
by this whole sidequest, don&#39;t see why we

needed the gang at all when Kiryu has taken
on bigger numbers by himself with just his

two fists and a communal seating area, and
I&#39;m less impressed by Yakuza 6 generally.

Yes, it&#39;s another idiosyncratic ball of Yakuza-brand
fun, but it feels lesser than its predecessors.

Less player characters, less depth, less complexity,
less all forget about it and play Yakuza 0
instead.
Ha ha.
